NHS England has extended the contract for Practitioner Health by a further 12 months to March 2026 while a review into all mental health services continues, Pulse has learned. In April, NHSE said
The post GP mental health service offer extended another year amid NHSE review appeared first on Pulse Today.
articles.title: GP mental health service offer extended another year amid NHSE review

articles.author: Anna Colivicchi
articles.description:
Patients at a GP practice in Wales are opposing a health board’s decision to close their surgery, and are ‘considering options’ to save it, including potentially buying its premises. Earlier this year, St David’s Surgery in North Pembrokeshire announced its decision to return its contract to Hywel Dda University Health Board and GP partner Dr Stephen Riley
The post Patients considering buying premises of GP practice set for closure appeared first on Pulse Today.
articles.title: Patients considering buying premises of GP practice set for closure

articles.author: Caroline Price
articles.description:
The next in our series of quick quizzes in paediatric care asks – what is the likely diagnosis in this case of a child with recent upper respiratory tract infection who has developed a rash?
The post Speediatrics: Can you solve this quick case involving a lower-limb rash? appeared first on Pulse Today.
articles.title: Speediatrics: Can you solve this quick case involving a lower-limb rash?

articles.author: Maya Dhillon
articles.description:
Our September 2024 survey of GPs working in the UK will cover a range of topics, including recruitment, unemployment and collective action. These are issues which are vital to the future of general practice and, as such, this is a comprehensive survey. Take the survey here Depending on your job role, it will take between
The post Take our September 2024 survey and potentially win £200 worth of vouchers appeared first on Pulse Today.
articles.title: Take our September 2024 survey and potentially win £200 worth of vouchers

articles.author: Sofia Lind
articles.description:
GPs should prescribe more triptans for the treatment of migraines, say researchers who found them to be the most effective option but underused. An extensive study by a team across Europe comparing all treatments found triptans to be more effective than newer more expensive drugs and traditional painkillers. Reporting in the BMJ, the team said
The post Triptans better than newer more expensive drugs for migraine, say researchers appeared first on Pulse Today.
articles.title: Triptans better than newer more expensive drugs for migraine, say researchers

articles.author: Eliza Parr
articles.description:
The RCGP will vote on a ‘scope of practice’ for physician associates (PAs) tomorrow which could give individual practices discretion to determine safe working for existing staff. Earlier this year, the college urged practices to ‘halt’ recruitment of PAs following a consultation which suggested that over 80% of GPs believe PAs in practices are having
The post RCGP to vote on physician associate scope of practice giving supervisors discretion appeared first on Pulse Today.
articles.title: RCGP to vote on physician associate scope of practice giving supervisors discretion

articles.author: Caroline Price
articles.description:
GP specialist in paediatrics Dr David Capehorn explains how to explore the differentials and course of action in a child who has developed a rash after a recent course of amoxicillin You see a two-year-old child with a widespread blanching erythematous macular rash which appeared the previous day. The background is that he saw a
The post Clinical conundrum: Child presents with rash after antibiotic treatment appeared first on Pulse Today.
articles.title: Clinical conundrum: Child presents with rash after antibiotic treatment

articles.author: Sofia Lind
articles.description:
Semaglutide may be an effective treatment for the skin condition hidradenitis suppurative, common in people with obesity, say researchers. A team in Ireland monitored outcomes for a small number of obese patients with varying degrees of hidradenitis suppurative who were taking a weekly dose of semaglutide. Patients reported fewer flare ups and improvements on quality-of-life
The post Semaglutide may help manage hidradenitis suppurative in obese patients appeared first on Pulse Today.
articles.title: Semaglutide may help manage hidradenitis suppurative in obese patients

articles.author: Eliza Parr
articles.description:
Exclusive GP partners facing ‘hundreds of thousands of pounds’ in legal costs have issued a warning to practices about the risks of ‘vicarious liability’.  Dr Matt Prendergast, a GP at the University Health Service Southampton, told Pulse that he and his partners are facing a claim in excess of £10m for the actions of their
The post GP partners facing £10m legal claim warn of ‘vicarious liability’ risks appeared first on Pulse Today.
articles.title: GP partners facing £10m legal claim warn of ‘vicarious liability’ risks

articles.author: Anna Colivicchi
articles.description:
Nearly 1,500 doctors, including GPs, have decided to take partial retirement in the past 10 months, new NHS data has revealed. According to data obtained through a Freedom of Information (FOI) request by specialist financial services mutual Wesleyan, 10,139 NHS Pension Scheme members have applied for partial retirement since the rules were changed last year.
The post Almost 1,500 doctors took partial retirement in the past year, NHS data shows appeared first on Pulse Today.
articles.title: Almost 1,500 doctors took partial retirement in the past year, NHS data shows

articles.author: Sofia Lind
articles.description:
The National Pharmacy Association (NPA) is balloting its members on working to rule amid growing concerns over funding and budget cuts, it has announced today. If passed, thousands of pharmacies across England, Wales and Northern Ireland could take collective action before Christmas, in an unprecedented move for the sector. The ballot, which will be sent
The post Pharmacists to vote on working to rule appeared first on Pulse Today.
articles.title: Pharmacists to vote on working to rule

articles.description: An NHS England director has said ICBs are using money earmarked for primary care to plug hospital deficits - and that she would 'love to reinstate' GP fellowships, but that the health service simply can't afford to in the current financial climate.
articles.title: Primary care cash 'stolen' for hospital deficits as official rues axing GP fellowships

articles.description: Updated NICE guidance on patients at risk of falls could shift responsibility for home hazard assessments from healthcare professionals to occupational therapists, as part of the first major update to the advice in more than a decade.
articles.title: Updated NICE guidance on falls could shift responsibility for home hazard checks

articles.description: The GPonline team discusses how the GP contract might change in the future and the RCGP's new guidance on the use of physician associates in general practice.
articles.title: Podcast: Future of the GP contract, what RCGP guidance means for PAs, assisted dying

articles.description: Disparities in fitness to practise referrals between ethnic minority and white doctors could be eradicated by 2026, the GMC has said - but the regulator warned inequality remains 'embedded in medicine' and called for cultural change.
articles.title: Fitness to practise referral disparities could end by 2026, says GMC

articles.description: One in three GPs say their practice premises are inadequate for providing patient care and a similar proportion say their work PC or laptop is not fit for purpose, according to damning findings from an RCGP poll.
articles.title: One in three GPs say their premises and computers are not fit for purpose

articles.description: GP practices in Northern Ireland are in a stand-off with health authorities after refusing to accept a short-notice demand to take on thousands of patients dispersed from a nearby practice that is closing down.
articles.title: Practice closure triggers stand-off as GPs refuse to accept list dispersal

articles.description: GPs and other healthcare professionals have called for an urgent independent review of obesity services in England to expand access to treatment, help clinicians prioritise access to new weight loss drugs and end a postcode lottery for patients.
articles.title: Doctors demand independent review of obesity services to end postcode lottery

articles.description: A damning final report on the operational effectiveness of the CQC confirms serious failings including inconsistent and unclear ratings, inspectors lacking expertise, long delays in re-inspecting organisations after a 'requires improvement' or 'inadequate' rating and a failure to listen people raising concerns.
articles.title: Lack of clarity, consistency and expertise: CQC failings exposed

articles.description: The CQC plans to step up inspections and simplify its assessment process after a report confirmed serious failings at the watchdog - as the government launched a further review that could call its future into doubt.
articles.title: CQC to step up inspections as government questions its future

articles.description: Creating GP jobs through the additional roles reimbursement scheme (ARRS) was a useful emergency solution but may not be the way to expand GP capacity 'forever', a senior NHS England official has suggested.
articles.title: ARRS may not be long-term solution to growing GP jobs, NHS official suggests

articles.description: Physician associates will be invited to register with the GMC from 16 December - but won't be legally required to do so for a further two years, the regulator has said.
articles.title: GMC announces start date for physician associate regulation

articles.description: Rising numbers of patients finding it easy to contact their GP practice represent 'green shoots of hope' for the profession after a period of intense criticism, NHS England's national director for primary care and community services has said.
articles.title: 'Green shoots of hope' amid rise in patients who say contacting GP practice is easy

articles.description: Talking General Practice speaks to GP Dr Rik Fijten and consultant hepatologist Dr Kosh Agarwal about the NHS in England’s drive to eliminate hepatitis C and how GPs can help with this programme.
articles.title: Podcast: Eliminating hepatitis C – the role of general practice

articles.description: BMA leaders have set out terms for a once-in-a-generation overhaul of the GP contract that could take effect from 2028.
articles.title: BMA sets out terms for major GP contract overhaul in 2028

articles.description: The RCGP has published comprehensive guidance on induction, supervision and the scope of practice for physician associates (PAs) - setting strict limits on the work they should carry out and support they need from GPs.
articles.title: RCGP guidance sets out strict limits on PA roles in general practice

articles.description: The BMA will financially support Anaesthetists United's legal case against the GMC, which is arguing that the regulator has failed to properly distinguish between qualified doctors and physician associates (PAs) and anaesthetic associates (AAs).
articles.title: BMA to financially support legal challenge against GMC over PAs

articles.description: BMA GP leaders have called on the government to increase core general practice funding per patient by £40 per year - 11p per day - from 2025/26 as a first step towards ending collective action.
articles.title: 11p more per patient per day could stop collective action, says BMA GP committee

articles.description: A former hospital trust chief executive has been appointed to lead a turnaround at the CQC, just months after the government declared the watchdog was 'not fit for purpose'.
articles.title: Former hospital boss brought in to overhaul 'not fit for purpose' CQC

articles.description: A new toolkit aimed at helping GP practices and pharmacies improve the consistency, safety and efficiency of repeat prescribing has been published by the Royal Pharmaceutical Society (RPS) and RCGP.
articles.title: First repeat prescribing guidance in 20 years aims to improve patient safety

articles.description: Funding and contracting models for general practice will need to change to deliver government plans for a neighbourhood health service, NHS leaders have said.
articles.title: GP contract and funding reform key steps towards 'neighbourhood NHS'

articles.description: Funding and contracting models for general practice will need to change to deliver government plans for a neighbourhood health service, NHS leaders have said.
articles.title: GP contract and funding reform could underpin shift to 'neighbourhood NHS'

articles.description: A GP has written a poetry book to help children aged between six and 11 learn about the human body through rhyme.
articles.title: GP writes children's poetry book about the human body

articles.description: A patient walked in and spraypainted obscenities in the reception area at the GP practice where RCGP president Dr Richard Vautrey works in recent weeks, the Leeds GP told the RCGP conference, in a passionate plea for an end to violence and abuse against GPs and practice staff.
articles.title: 'End the hate': RCGP president's plea after spraypaint attack on practice

articles.description: Reductions in general practice funding in Northern Ireland are making it increasingly difficult for practices to survive, GP leaders have warned, after official figures showed substantial real-terms cuts in funding in the past two financial years.
articles.title: Declining funding making it harder for practices to stay open, warn Northern Ireland GPs

articles.description: Talking General Practice looks at what health and social care secretary Wes Streeting had to say at the RCGP annual conference and speaks to the college's vice chair for professional development Professor Margaret Ikpoh, treasurer Dr Steve Mowle and First 5 chair Dr Toyosi Adeniji.
articles.title: Podcast: RCGP conference – Wes Streeting on ‘bulldozing' bureaucracy and collective action, challenges facing new GPs

articles.description: Health and social care secretary Wes Streeting called on general practice to halt collective action, promised a bureaucracy-busting drive to free up GP time and longer-term funding for GP ARRS jobs, and faced questions around visas and other issues at the 2024 RCGP annual conference. GPonline asked GPs at the event for their reaction.
articles.title: How did GPs react to Wes Streeting’s RCGP conference speech?

articles.description: In a keynote speech at the 2024 RCGP annual conference, Wes Streeting highlighted the government's plans for the NHS, pledged to 'bulldoze bureaucracy' in general practice and called on GPs to step back from collective action, saying it would only punish patients. Read the speech in full.
articles.title: Health and social care secretary Wes Streeting: RCGP conference speech in full

articles.description: Winners of the annnual RCGP/Marie Curie Daffodil Standards awards, which recognise the contribution general practice teams have made to providing excellent end-of-life care, have been announced.
articles.title: GPs and practices recognised for providing excellent end-of-life care

articles.description: Creating a single patient record that offers clinicians across primary and secondary care services 'a full picture' of patients they treat will be a key part of the government's forthcoming 10-year NHS plan, the health and social care secretary has said.
articles.title: Single patient record bridging GP practices and hospitals to form key part of 10-year NHS plan

articles.description: Women with worrying breast lumps will be able to book appointments directly with breast diagnostic clinics without first seeing their GP in an NHS pilot that aims to free up time in general practice and speed up cancer diagnosis.
articles.title: Women with 'red flag' breast lumps to bypass GP visits in NHS trial

articles.description: Health and social care secretary Wes Streeting has said the government will introduce legislation to create a single register of GPs and specialist doctors.
articles.title: Government pledges legislation to merge GP and specialist registers

articles.description: Health and social care secretary Wes Streeting has said the government will introduce legislation to create a single register of GPs and specialist doctors.
articles.title: Streeting pledges legislation to merge GP and specialist registers

articles.description: Funding for more than 1,000 GP jobs created through an £82m expansion of the additional roles reimbursement scheme (ARRS) from this month will be guaranteed beyond the end of the current financial year, the health and social care secretary has confirmed.
articles.title: Funding for GP ARRS jobs will continue beyond March, says Streeting

articles.description: Health and social care secretary Wes Streeting has promised to 'bulldoze bureaucracy' to free up GP time - but also called on the profession to step back from measures over 80% of practices are taking to reduce workload as part of collective action.
articles.title: Streeting urges GPs to stop collective action, warning 'patient care will suffer'

articles.description: Health and social care secretary Wes Streeting will promise today to 'bulldoze bureaucracy' to free up GP time - but will also call on the profession to step back from measures over 80% of practices are taking to reduce workload as part of collective action.
articles.title: Streeting calls on GPs to step back from collective action

articles.description: PCNs will struggle to afford pay uplifts for thousands of additional roles reimbursement scheme (ARRS) staff this year because funding has not increased in line with updated rates of pay, GP leaders have warned.
articles.title: Unfunded ARRS pay uplift leaves GP resources 'squeezed even tighter'

articles.description: PCNs are being destabilised because staff are quitting their jobs over ‘inequitable funding’, an organisation representing practice managers has warned.
articles.title: PCN staff quitting jobs due to ‘inequitable funding,’ practice managers warn

articles.description: The winners of the RCGP Research Paper of the Year have been announced at the college’s annual conference.
articles.title: RCGP Research Paper of the Year winners announced

articles.description: Talking General Practice highlights key events from day one of the conference and speaks to college safeguarding lead Dr Joy Shacklock about the RCGP's new safeguarding standards and Dr Catherine Millington-Sanders, the RCGP clinical lead for palliative and end-of-life care.
articles.title: Podcast: RCGP annual conference – Health inequalities, new safeguarding standards, end-of-life care

articles.description: Lessons from the COVID-19 pandemic response can help general practice tackle rising long-term conditions and health inequalities, a leading public health professor has told the RCGP conference.
articles.title: COVID response could inform GPs' approach to long-term conditions and inequality

articles.description: General practice needs a new outcomes-based contract with the flexibility for local GPs to build services around the needs of their patients, the head of a major charity coalition has said.
articles.title: GPs need a flexible new contract to build services around patients, say charities

articles.description: Without GPs there is no NHS - but general practice has long been undervalued and deserves better, says Professor Kamila Hawthorne. In a keynote speech at the 2024 RCGP annual conference, the college chair urged the government to work with the profession to shape the future of the health service. Read the speech in full below.
articles.title: Professor Kamila Hawthorne: RCGP conference speech in full

articles.description: GPs in deprived areas are responsible for hundreds more patients each and 'devastating inequality' in general practice provision is rising, RCGP chair Professor Kamila Hawthorne will warn today.
articles.title: 'Devastating inequality' in GP provision is growing, RCGP chair warns

articles.description: GPs in England's most deprived areas are caring for hundreds more patients each than their counterparts in better-off parts of the country. GPonline looks at what RCGP analysis of inequality in GP provision shows.
articles.title: How many more patients per GP are there in deprived areas?

articles.description: The RCGP has called for a 'public commitment' from NHS England that GP jobs created through the additional roles reimbursement scheme (ARRS) will continue beyond March 2025.
articles.title: RCGP demands longer funding guarantee for GP ARRS jobs

articles.description: The RCGP has called for a step change in efforts to retain GPs ahead of its 2024 annual conference, warning that the cycle of expanding general practice training only to allow doctors to ‘trickle away’ must stop.
articles.title: NHS must end cycle of training more GPs and watching them leave, says RCGP chair

articles.description: In the first of three daily episodes of Talking General Practice from the RCGP annual conference, college chair Professor Kamila Hawthorne discusses health inequalities, physician associates and her views on what the new government means for general practice.
articles.title: Podcast: RCGP chair Professor Kamila Hawthorne on GP retention, health inequalities and physician associates

articles.description: The doctor-owned triage and consultation platform eConsult - used by more than half of UK GP practices - has been bought by a tech company for an undisclosed amount.
articles.title: GP triage and consultation platform eConsult bought out by tech firm

articles.description: Royal colleges have urged the government and NHS England to carry out a rapid review into the safety, cost-effectiveness and efficiency of physician associates.
articles.title: Medical royal colleges demand rapid review into physician associate roles

articles.description: Funding available to recruit GPs through the additional roles reimbursement scheme (ARRS) is a 'drop in the ocean of what is needed' and the roles could create significant financial risks for PCNs and practices, experts have warned.
articles.title: ARRS GP funding 'nowhere near enough' and creates 'significant risks'

articles.description: Funding available to recruit GPs through the additional roles reimbursement scheme (ARRS) is a 'drop in the ocean of what is needed' and the roles could create significant financial risks for PCNs and practices, experts have warned.
articles.title: ARRS GP funding 'nowhere near enough' and leaves GPs facing 'significant risks'

articles.description: The next round of pay uplifts for doctors is 'unlikely' to kick in when the 2025/26 financial year begins in April, but the timeline for pay awards could be 'more fully reset' by the following year, the government has said.
articles.title: GP funding uplifts to kick in earlier from next year, says Streeting

articles.description: One in 10 GPs expected their practice to close or hand back its contract within a year and 42% expected to leave the profession within five years, according to RCGP polling carried out in the run-up to the general election.
articles.title: Pre-election poll found one in 10 GPs expected practice closure within a year

articles.description: Falling flu vaccination rates are of 'real concern' after more than 18,000 deaths associated with influenza over the past two years, the UK Health Security Agency (UKHSA) has warned.
articles.title: Call to improve flu jab uptake after 18,000 deaths in two years

articles.description: Digital tools can speed up patients' experience of booking appointments like self-checkouts have in supermarkets, a former BMA chair has said - but practices need funding to teach patients how to use them and to maintain phone access for patients who can't.
articles.title: Digital tools can speed up GP access but won't suit all patients, warns former BMA chair

articles.description: GPs employed under the additional roles reimbursement scheme (ARRS) must have qualified within the last two years and not previously been employed in a substantive GP post in a practice, NHS England has confirmed.
articles.title: Details of GP ARRS plans revealed in updated network contract DES

articles.description: A standard process for recording and responding to patient safety incidents in primary care will be introduced in general practice from this year, NHS England has said.
articles.title: GPs asked to record patient safety incidents on national system

articles.description: NHS England has said it intends to learn lessons from the nuclear power industry to help improve patient safety in primary care.
articles.title: NHS to learn lessons from nuclear industry to improve patient safety in primary care

articles.description: The full-time equivalent (FTE) fully-qualified GP workforce in England rose during the past year, but the number of partners has continued to fall, latest data show.
articles.title: Rise in GP workforce over past year but number of partners continues to fall

articles.description: The full-time equivalent (FTE) fully-qualified GP workforce rose in the past year, but the number of partners has continued to fall, latest data show.
articles.title: Rise in GP workforce over past year but partners continue to fall

articles.description: Continuity of care and GPs employed under the additional roles reimbursement scheme (ARRS) will be part of GP contract negotiations this year, health minister Stephen Kinnock has said.
articles.title: Continuity of care and GP ARRS roles will be part of GP contract negotiations, says health minister

articles.description: NHS England has released details of the 22 PCNs taking part in its controversial GP operating model pilot that could be the basis for future GP contract reform.
articles.title: PCNs taking part in NHS England GP operating model pilot named

articles.description: The government will focus on 'building up local health services' in deprived areas so that patients have more choice about when and where they are treated, the health and social care secretary has said.
articles.title: Long-term NHS plan will give patients in deprived areas more choice, says Streeting

articles.description: Labour’s new GP MP has said he believes any additional funding the NHS receives will be spent on community and GP services as part of the government’s drive to build a ‘neighbourhood NHS'.
articles.title: Labour’s new GP MP says primary care will be prioritised for any new NHS funding

articles.description: The government has yet to respond to the BMA’s letter raising concerns that GPs employed under the additional roles reimbursement scheme (ARRS) could be on less favourable terms than the salaried GP model contract.
articles.title: Government yet to respond to BMA letter raising concerns over ARRS GP plan

articles.description: Doctors' leaders have called for an overhaul of how the NHS reports data on GP working hours to prevent under-representation of their time commitment.
articles.title: Overhaul how NHS measures GP working hours, say doctors' leaders

articles.description: Physician associates (PAs) have a role to play in the NHS, but doctors' concerns about how they are working must be taken seriously, the health and social care secretary Wes Streeting has said.
articles.title: Streeting backs role for physician associates in NHS despite RCGP vote

articles.description: Physician associates (PAs) have a role to play in the NHS, but doctors' concerns about how they are working must be taken seriously, the health and social care secretary Wes Streeting has said.
articles.title: Streeting backs role for physician associates in NHS following RCGP vote

articles.description: The annual national vaccination catch-up campaign, which forms part of the GP contract in England, will focus on the maternal pertussis programme this year amid concern about rising cases and recent infant deaths.
articles.title: GP vaccination catch-up campaign to target pertussis jabs for pregnant women

articles.description: The specialist mental health service for doctors NHS Practitioner Health has secured funding to ensure it can continue to provide care to doctors and NHS staff until March 2026.
articles.title: NHS Practitioner Health secures funding for further 12 months

articles.description: A scheme that provides remote monitoring to patients with long-term conditions and frailty has led to a reduction in GP visits, A&E attendances, hospital admissions and outpatient appointments.
articles.title: Remote patient monitoring scheme cuts GP visits, A&E attendances and admissions

articles.description: Too many children are unprotected against serious, preventable illnesses, experts warned after uptake of child vaccinations fell on all 14 coverage measures monitored by the NHS and the UK Health Security Agency (UKHSA).
articles.title: Child vaccine uptake drops as experts warn of preventable illness risk

articles.description: The RCGP has said it opposes any role for physician associates (PAs) working in general practice, following a vote by its governing council on Friday (20 September).
articles.title: RCGP votes to oppose physician associate roles in general practice

articles.description: Plans to create more than 1,000 GP jobs through the additional roles reimbursement scheme (ARRS) are highly unlikely to start in October, GP leaders have warned.
articles.title: 'Almost impossible' for GP ARRS jobs to start in October, LMC warns

articles.description: A GP practice was forced to close after triggering an emergency alert when a patient arrived covered in white powder.
articles.title: Emergency closure at GP practice after patient arrived 'covered in white powder'

articles.description: In our regular news review, the GPonline team looks in detail at what the Darzi review had to say and what it could mean for general practice and the latest on GP collective action.
articles.title: Podcast: What next for general practice and the NHS after the Darzi review?

articles.description: Health secretary Wes Streeting has agreed to speak at this year’s RCGP Annual Conference - offering GPs the chance to quiz him on the government’s plans for general practice.
articles.title: Health secretary Wes Streeting to speak at RCGP Annual Conference 2024

articles.description: Plans to introduce a 'neighbourhood NHS' will not mean scrapping the GP partnership model, the health and social care secretary has said.
articles.title: Labour won't scrap GP partnerships to build neighbourhood NHS, says Streeting

articles.description: Tens of thousands of children and eligible adults living with type 1 diabetes across England are set to receive an ‘artificial pancreas’ thanks to cost-effective deals secured by the NHS with suppliers of the technology. articles.author: nowen
articles.description: Around one in eight children aged between two and 10 in England are obese, an NHS survey published today found. New statistics show around one in seven children (15%) aged between two and 15 were obese in 2022 – similar to 2019 (16%). Obesity rates in 2022 were 12% among those aged between two and 10, […]
articles.title: One in eight toddlers and primary school aged children obese

articles.author: nowen
articles.description: Millions of people in England can book flu and COVID-19 vaccinations from today (Monday, 23 September) as the NHS rolls out additional protection for those most at risk ahead of winter. Anyone eligible can book their vaccinations from 9am via the NHS website, by downloading the NHS App, or by calling 119 for free if they […]
articles.title: NHS booking opens for life-saving flu and COVID-19 vaccinations

articles.author: nowen
articles.description: Searches for NHS advice on laryngeal cancer saw an increase of 1277% following Jamie Theakston’s cancer diagnosis announcement – that’s one visit every 16 seconds across the two days since his Instagram post. Earlier this week, radio presenter Jamie said: “I have cancer… But cancer doesn’t have me! The prognosis is very positive and I’m hoping to […]
articles.title: NHS cancer advice page sees a visit every 16 seconds following Jamie Theakston’s diagnosis

articles.author: rwootton
articles.description: NHS patients with an aggressive form of blood cancer are to benefit from a life-extending daily tablet after the health service became Europe’s first to routinely commission the treatment. The new targeted treatment, quizartinib, can now be prescribed to newly-diagnosed patients with a specific type of leukaemia, boosting their chance of remission and long-term survival. […]
articles.title: NHS England fast-tracks new life-extending blood cancer treatment

articles.title: Mirror, mirror 2024: a portrait of the failing U.S. health system — comparing performance in 10 nations

articles.description: Institute of Health Equity - To better tackle health inequalities in Leeds and enable the city to maximise its opportunities, the Fairer, Healthier Leeds programme was launched in June 2023. This report draws on learning from the programme’s first year and provides a short analysis of health inequalities in Leeds, recommends action to reduce them and ways to improve the...
articles.title: Fairer, Healthier Leeds: reducing health inequalities

articles.description: Policy Exchange - This report – based upon more than forty interviews and the findings of FOI requests to every trust and integrated care board in England – considers the role that management and leadership can play in enhancing NHS performance and productivity. It argues that a greater focus on the competencies, permissions and placement of management is required, noting...
articles.title: Just about managing: the role of effective management and leadership in improving NHS performance and productivity

articles.description: Institute for Government - The UK government spends up to £400bn each year on buying in goods and services. However, the PPE and Horizon scandals show recent governments have not always spent his public money well. This joint Institute for Government, Tussell and AutogenAI report looks at the size and shape of public procurement in the UK, and opportunities for...
articles.title: Improving accountability in government procurement

It includes a jargon buster and various case studies on how AI is currently being used in some NHS trusts. NHS Confederation - publications

The review examines options for putting the New Hospital Programme onto an affordable and deliverable footing. Guidance Department of Health and Social Care - publications
articles.title: New Hospital Programme review: terms of reference

It highlights common issues impacting on the quality and safety of NHS hospital maternity services across the country. Report Maternity improvement resources Care Quality Commission - press release
articles.title: National review of maternity services in England 2022 to 2024

Nuffield Trust - publications
articles.title: Assisted dying legislation will have a big impact on end of life care: what is the state of play for services in England?

articles.description:
On 16 October, the Ministry of Public Health of Lebanon confirmed a cholera case, highlighting the escalating health risks amidst ongoing conflict. The case was identified in Akkar governorate in the north of the country, marking the first case since the October 2022-June 2023 outbreak was declared over. Authorities are investigating the extent of the disease’s spread, gathering samples from the patient’s contacts, and assessing potential water contamination. 
“WHO has been sounding the alarm on the risk of emerging infectious diseases like cholera resurfacing in Lebanon as a result of poor water and sanitation conditions and the impact of the current conflict.” said Dr Abdinasir Abubakar, WHO Representative in Lebanon. “Our immediate focus now is to enhance surveillance and water sanitati…
articles.title: WHO in Lebanon working to stop cholera spread amid conflict

articles.description:
Geneva 17 October 2024 – This afternoon, His Excellency Mr Jérôme Bonnafont, Permanent Representative of France to the United Nations in Geneva, and WHO Director-General Dr Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus met in the WHO headquarters for the signing of seven contribution agreements.

The contribution totalling €24 million comes through the Ministry of Europe & Foreign Affairs. It fits in the France–WHO Framework Agreement for 2020 to 2025, which provides both a strategic framework for engagement, aligned with WHO priorities, while providing legal, administrative and financial instruments for operationalizing collaboration.
This latest contribution includes a generous €4.5 million in fully flexible voluntary funds for the Core Voluntary Contributions Account (CVCA).
Additionally, France will supp…
articles.title: Signing ceremony for contribution agreements between WHO and France

articles.description: A new report on “Refugee and Migrant Health System Review: Challenges and Opportunities for Long-term Health System Strengthening in Uganda” calls for a holistic approach to fortifying Uganda’s health system.
articles.title: New joint health system review highlights opportunities for strengthening health care services for refugees and migrant communities in Uganda.

articles.description:
Parliamentarians from across the globe gathered at the UNITE Global Summit in Berlin to sign a statement in support of the World Health Organization Pandemic Agreement. The statement, signed by the President of UNITE, members of its board, and parliamentarians around the world, marks a significant commitment from parliamentarians to strengthen pandemic preparedness, response, and equitable access to health. 
“Parliamentarians are the voice of the people and have a crucial responsibility in safeguarding public health,” said Ricardo Baptista Leite, President of UNITE. “The WHO Pandemic Agreement represents a historic opportunity to prevent pandemics and strengthen our global preparedness and response capabilities. By signing this statement, we are not only showing our support for the agreeme…
articles.title: Parliamentarians Unite in Berlin to Sign Global Statement Supporting the WHO Pandemic Agreement

articles.description:
Since the escalation of hostilities between Israel and Lebanon on 17 September 2024, WHO has verified 23 attacks on health care in Lebanon that have led to 72 deaths and 43 injuries among health workers and patients. Fifteen incidents impacted health facilities, while 13 impacted health transport. Hospitals in Lebanon are already under massive strain as they strive to sustain essential health services while dealing with an unprecedented influx of injured people. Understaffed and under-resourced, the health system has been struggling to maintain uninterrupted services to all those in need with supplies being depleted and health workers exhausted.
Increasing conflict, intense bombardment and insecurity are forcing a growing number of health facilities to shut down, particularly in the south.…
articles.title: Attacks on hospitals and health workers jeopardize provision of health in Lebanon

articles.description:
In a powerful demonstration of high-level support, the World Health Organization (WHO) today received nearly US$ 700 million in new funding commitments from European countries, foundations and others, and another US$ 300 million in reaffirmed commitments.
Announced at the WHO Investment Round Signature Event at the World Health Summit in Berlin hosted by Germany, France, and Norway, the commitments highlighted the urgent need for investments in the Organization’s mission to improve health outcomes worldwide. 
The world’s global health strategy, WHO's Fourteenth General Programme of Work 2025-2028, was approved by WHO’s 194 Member States at the World Health Assembly in May. The Organization’s first ever Investment Round, also launched at the Assembly, aims to ensure that WHO has the predict…
articles.title: US$ 1 billion in new and reaffirmed funding commitments announced for WHO’s ongoing Investment Round

articles.description: Capturing and building on the experiences of the FIFA World Cup Qatar 2022, the State of Qatar and World Health Organization today launched a new report providing lessons learned and recommendations for staging healthy and safe mega and grassroots sporting events around the world.
articles.title: Qatar-WHO partnership leaves legacy for safer, healthier mega-sporting events

articles.description:
The WHO Youth Council has launched its first Youth Declaration on Creating Healthy Societies, with a range of calls to action informed and developed by young people from around the world and geared towards empowering youth to play a central role in creating healthier and safer societies for all.
"The WHO Youth Council is proud to be issuing its first Youth Declaration on Creating Healthy Societies," said Kate Ndocko, WHO Youth Council member. "This Declaration represents our collective commitment and priorities to help communities, especially youth, at local, regional and global levels, to be healthier and more resilient in the face of the many health challenges the world faces today as well as the ones ahead."
The Declaration was launched today during the World Health Summit taking place …
articles.title: WHO Youth Council releases bold call for a healthier world

articles.description:
The second round of an emergency polio vaccination campaign is scheduled to start on 14 October 2024 in Gaza, to vaccinate an estimated 591 700 children under ten years of age with a second dose of the novel oral polio vaccine type 2 (nOPV2) vaccine.
This follows a first round, which was successfully implemented from 1-12 September 2024 and vaccinated 559 161 children, or an estimated 95% of eligible children at governorate level, according to independently conducted post-campaign monitoring. As with the first round, the second round will have three phases, each involving three campaign days and one catch-up day.
A minimum of two doses of nOPV2 are needed to interrupt poliovirus transmission. However, this will only be achieved if at least 90% of all children are vaccinated in all communit…
articles.title: Second round of polio vaccination in the Gaza Strip aims to vaccinate over half a million children

articles.description:
A new report by the World Health Organization (WHO) finds that vaccines against 24 pathogens could reduce the number of antibiotics needed by 22% or 2.5 billion defined daily doses globally every year, supporting worldwide efforts to address antimicrobial resistance (AMR). While some of these vaccines are already available but underused, others would need to be developed and brought to the market as soon as possible.
AMR occurs when bacteria, viruses, fungi, and parasites no longer respond to antimicrobial medicines, making people sicker and increasing the risk of illness, death and the spread of infections that are difficult to treat. AMR is driven largely by the misuse and overuse of antimicrobials, yet, at the same time, many people around the world do not have access to essential antim…
articles.title: Better use of vaccines could reduce antibiotic use by 2.5 billion doses annually, says WHO

articles.description:
The World Health Organization (WHO) and the Kingdom of the Netherlands have renewed their strategic partnership in addressing the growing impacts of climate change on global health.
The Netherlands is providing a new allocation of €500 000 for 2024 to WHO, reinforcing its commitment to climate resilience and sustainable healthcare systems worldwide. This allocation supports WHO’s ongoing efforts to strengthen the Alliance for Transformative Action on Climate and Health Secretariat and advance climate change and health programmes globally.
This contribution builds on the partnership established in 2023 between the Netherlands and WHO to collaborate on climate change and health. Together, they have supported African, Asian and Eastern Mediterranean countries in advancing the implementation o…
articles.title: WHO and the Netherlands renew their partnership on climate change and health

articles.description: The WHO Technical Advisory Group on COVID-19 Vaccine Composition (TAG-CO-VAC) continues to closely monitor the genetic and antigenic evolution of SARS-CoV-2 variants, immune responses to SARS-CoV-2 infection and COVID-19 vaccination, and the performance of COVID-19 vaccines against circulating variants. Based on these evaluations, WHO advises vaccine manufacturers and regulatory authorities on the implications for future updates to COVID-19 vaccine antigen composition. The next decision-making meeting of the TAG-CO-VAC is scheduled for mid-December 2024, after which a statement on COVID-19 vaccine antigen composition and an accompanying data annex will be published on the WHO website. These meetings are timed to balance the availability of the latest epidemiological, immunological, and vir…
articles.title: Types of data requested to inform December 2024 COVID-19 vaccine antigen composition deliberations

articles.description:
The Heads of the International Monetary Fund (IMF), the World Bank Group (WBG), and the World Health Organization (WHO) have agreed on broad principles for cooperation on pandemic preparedness. This cooperation will allow a scaling up of support to countries to prevent, detect and respond to public health threats through the IMF’s Resilience and Sustainability Trust (RST), the WBG’s financial and technical support, and WHO’s technical expertise and in-country capabilities. The RST allows eligible member countries to access long-term financing at low interest rates to help implement reforms that address structural challenges to the stability of the economy, such as those posed by pandemics, and to enhance countries’ health systems resilience.
Operating within their respective mandates and p…
articles.title: The International Monetary Fund, the World Bank Group, and the World Health Organization step up cooperation on pandemic preparedness

articles.description:
The World Health Organization (WHO) has listed the first mpox in vitro diagnostic (IVD) under its Emergency Use Listing (EUL) procedure, an important step in improving global access to mpox testing. The approval for emergency use of the Alinity m MPXV assay, manufactured by Abbott Molecular Inc., will be pivotal in expanding diagnostic capacity in countries facing mpox outbreaks, where the need for quick and accurate testing has risen sharply. Early diagnosis of mpox enables timely treatment and care, and control of the virus.
Limited testing capacity and delays in confirming mpox cases persist in Africa, contributing to the continued spread of the virus. In 2024, over 30 000 suspected cases have been reported across the region, with the highest numbers in the Democratic Republic of the Co…
articles.title: WHO approves first mpox diagnostic test for emergency use, boosting global access

articles.description: Today, the World Health Organization (WHO) launched the Global Strategic Preparedness, Readiness and Response Plan (SPRP) to tackle dengue and other Aedes-borne arboviruses.
articles.title: WHO launches global strategic plan to fight rising dengue and other Aedes-borne arboviral diseases

articles.title: Brazil eliminates lymphatic filariasis as a public health problem

articles.description: The World Health Organization (WHO) today announced the recommendations for the viral composition of influenza vaccines for the 2025 influenza season in the southern hemisphere. The announcement was made at an information session after a 4-day meeting on the Composition of Influenza Virus Vaccines. The meeting is held twice annually, once for the southern and once for the northern hemisphere.
articles.title: Recommendations announced for influenza vaccine composition for the 2025 southern hemisphere influenza season

articles.description: Global leaders have approved a political declaration at the 79th United Nations General Assembly (UNGA) High-Level Meeting on Antimicrobial Resistance (AMR), committing to a clear set of targets and actions, including reducing the estimated 4.95 million human deaths associated with bacterial antimicrobial resistance (AMR) annually by 10% by 2030.
articles.title: World leaders commit to decisive action on antimicrobial resistance

articles.description:
The World Health Organization (WHO) today released guidance to improve the design, conduct and oversight of clinical trials in countries of all income levels. This guidance aims to support stronger country-led research and development (R&D) ecosystems to advance health science so that new, safe and effective health interventions can be made more accessible and affordable globally for people everywhere, faster. 
For the first time, WHO offers recommendations for national health authorities, regulatory authorities, funders and others on how they can best facilitate clinical trials to generate evidence on health interventions. It addresses challenges such as poor trial design, limited diversity of participants, insufficient infrastructure and bureaucratic efficiencies, which cost time, money …
articles.title: New global guidance puts forward recommendations for more effective and equitable clinical trials

articles.description:
Execution is starting under the new Health Impact Investment Platform on the first country health investment plans turning original commitment into operational reality. The landmark partnership between Multilateral Development Banks (MDBs), the World Health Organization (WHO) and low- and middle-income countries (LMICs) is addressing the critical need for coordinated efforts to strengthen primary healthcare (PHC) in vulnerable and underserved communities to build resilience against pandemic threats like mpox and the climate crisis. 
At the high-level roundtable meeting in New York on the margins of the UN Summit of the Future in New York today, new funding was signed, and it was agreed that the partners will sit down and start identifying needs and planning health care improvements in 15 c…
articles.title: WHO and multilateral development banks kick off US$ 1.5 billion primary health financing platform with new funds and launch of first investment plans in 15 countries

articles.description:
An investment today of an additional US$0.24 per patient per year in digital health interventions, such as telemedicine, mobile messaging and chatbots, can help save more than 2 million lives from noncommunicable diseases over the next decade, says a new report released jointly by the World Health Organization (WHO) and ITU (International Telecommunication Union). This investment could also avert approximately 7 million acute events and hospitalizations, significantly reducing the strain on healthcare systems around the world.
The publication titled "Going digital for noncommunicable diseases: the case for action" has been launched at an event hosted by the Government of The Gambia during the 79th United Nations General Assembly, in collaboration with the ITU and WHO. 
“The future of healt…
articles.title: Boosting digital health can help prevent millions of deaths from noncommunicable diseases

articles.description:
Increased investment is urgently needed to address evolving health risks and meet the mental and sexual and reproductive health needs for the nearly 1.3 billion adolescents (aged 10-19 years) globally, according to a new scientific publication released by the World Health Organization (WHO).  Adolescence is a unique and critical stage of human development, involving major physical, emotional, and social transitions, and is a pivotal window for laying long-term foundations for good health.
“Promoting and protecting the health and rights of young people is essential to building a better future for our world,” said Dr Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus, Director-General of WHO. “Conversely, failing to address the health threats that adolescents face – some longstanding, some emerging – will not only …
articles.title: Securing adolescent health and well-being today is vital for the health of future generations - WHO

articles.description:
These atrocities must end
As world leaders gather in New York for the 79th United Nations General Assembly, and as the threat of a wider regional escalation looms, we renew our demand for an end to the appalling human suffering and humanitarian catastrophe in Gaza.
We mourn the loss of innocent life everywhere, including those killed on October 7 and during the 11 months of conflict since then. 
We urgently call for a sustained, immediate and unconditional ceasefire. This is the only way to end the suffering of civilians and save lives.
All hostages and all those arbitrarily detained must be released immediately and unconditionally. 
Humanitarians must have safe and unimpeded access to those in need.
We cannot do our jobs in the face of overwhelming need and ongoing violence. More than 41,…
articles.title:
Statement by Principals of the 
Inter-Agency Standing Committee 
on the situation in the 
Occupied Palestinian Territory

articles.description:
The World Health Organization (WHO) and partners will call on world leaders to address critical global health challenges, and invest in global public health, at meetings throughout the high-level week of the   79th session of the United Nations General Assembly (UNGA79), to be held in New York from 20 to 30 September 2024. 
The second   High-Level Meeting on Antimicrobial Resistance (AMR) on 26 September 2024 will be the principal official, health-focused event during the UNGA high-level week. Without decisive action, such as that outlined in the final text of the draft political declaration for the  meeting, AMR will cause even more global suffering, particularly in low- and middle-income countries. Antimicrobial resistance (AMR) occurs when bacteria, viruses, fungi and parasites no longe…
articles.title: WHO at UNGA: Call for urgent, high-level action to address global scourge of antimicrobial resistance
